captions.text: What it do comrade? I read yo comments - and this week on Thug Notes we going HAM with Animal Farm by
George Orwell.

S’all gravy up at the Manor Farm
‘til one night a prize boar by the name

of Old Major has a trippy-ass dream. So this
porker hollers at his animal homies to preach
some o dat raw gospel.

Major say that men are the only
creature on the farm that consume errything,

but don’t produce nothin. Which means the
only thing standing between them animals and

righteous livin is steppin to and stompin
their two-legged oppressors. Rebellion, dog!

One night, the animals rise up and
kick farmer Jones and his boys straight to

the curb. Finally the boss of they own turf,
the animals re-dub this bad boy “Animal

Farm” and lay down a new rap called “Animalism.
Up in this crib, the main verse is that all
animals are equal.

After the dust settle, two pigs
named Napoleon and Snowball start callin the

shots. Thing is, they always gettin up in
eachothers grill.

When some humans try to throw down
and take back the farm, those animals don’t

play- they straight beast these fools and
send em packin.

Then Napoleon and Snowball start
beefin bout the idea of building a windmill.

When the other animals start siding with Snowball,
Napoleon gets all crunk and chases him off

the farm. Another pig named Squealer start
tellin errybody that Snowball wasn’t nothin
but a snitch and a traitor.

Now while all the other animals busting their
ass building that

windmill, the pigs realize that some of da
swag they need, they just can’t get on their

own. So they hit up their two legged enemies
and startin tradin with them on the reg.

Over time, the seven Commandments
of Animalism get twisted little by little,

until one day, only one remains: “All animals
are equal, but some animals are more equal
than others.”

Eventually, the pigs get so crooked
that they start struttin exactly like humans-

walkin two-legged wit whips of oppression
in hand.

And in the end, they ain’t nobody
can tell the difference between pigs and humans.
Looks like we back where we started.

Listen up, comrade. This book ain’t
just a story bout animals.

On the real, Orwell droppin some
mad allegory bout the rise and fall of da
Soviet Union.

See, the pigs representin the top
dawgs of the communist party. Napoleon stands

for Stalin, the Soviet dictator, whereas Snowball
really be Trotsky, the communist leader whose

beef with Stalin got his ass slung out of
Russia.

Squealer’s smooth talkin tendencies
representin Pravda, a newspaper that spit

lies to the people in order to further Stalin’s
cause.

Old Major is a mix of Karl Marx,
the OG commie theorist, and Vladimir Lenin,

the brain behind the revolution. When Old
Major preachin to the animals, his rhyme got

the same flava as the end of The Communist
Manifesto.

Also, the animal’s revolt in
chapter 2 echoin’ the Bolshevik Revolution of

of October 1917 against the czar, who be Mr.
Jones in the story. And the humans’ attempt

to retake the farm in chapter 4 reppin the
civil war between the Russian loyalists and
Bolsheviks in 1918.

Now of all things, why did Orwell use animals
to chop game bout The

Soviet Union? Check this quote from Karl Marx’s
Economic and Philosophical Manuscript of 1844:

But 
Animal Farm ain’t just goin off
bout one point in history. This book offerin

some legit truths bout all humanity. Cuz no
matter who you wit, power can corrupt yo mind.

And even the realest homies, like Boxer, are
liable to start worshipping a crooked ass
leader.

But you know what’s mad ironic, B?
If you keepin it literal up in here, the revolution

that went down at Manor farm was actually
legit. By definition, a revolution ends where

it began. Cuz the porky playas that started
out gettin fu**ed by their human oppressors,
are now the ones doin the fu**in.

Yo show your colors and get yoself
a Thug Notes t-shirt, son! See yo ass next week playa!

title: Animal Farm - Thug Notes Summary and Analysis

comments.text:
+LackingSaint I have a few things to say:


1. There is no such thing as a gender wage gap, that claim has no 
scientific basis of any  kind, has no evidence what so ever that isn't 
poorly researched or incredibly biased and it even contradicts common sense.

2. Popular showing media showing more men than women as main 
characters have nothing to do with oppression. They just want to 
appeal to a target demographic, the bigger the demographic the better. Man 
Of Steel and Avengers 2 appeal to a mostly male demographic while Twilight 
and 50 Shades Of Grey appeal to a mostly female one.

3. Why do you even care about something that trivial?
 Will that make the world any better?
Of course not. It doesn't matter if the majority of the world's leaders are 
male or female, what matters is if they are capable of solving the world 
problems.

4. I know that women in major parts of the world are treated poorly and 
they need all the feminism they can handle. But here in the developed 
world, where there is nothing stopping a woman from pursuing the same 
career as her male counterparts including becoming the leader of her 
nation, I don't see why feminism is in any way necessary anymore.
comments.author: Theodor Tronét

comments.text:

oppressed" and "women are oppressors". That's why right now, women earn 
exactly the same as men, popular media shows women as main characters just 
as much as men, we have as just as many female leaders as men, and there 
aren't major parts of the world where women are treated like second-class 
citizens.

"The oppressed become the oppressors" misses any amount of nuance Orwell 
was communicating in the novel, and your analogy is massively off-base.

comments.author: KoR x Legacy

comments.text:
As a teenager, I have to say that this account is such a great idea! A lot 
of the other kids in my school would never read books like this, but when I 
showed them this video they were entertained and incredibly excited to read 
the book! The analysis and summary of the books are well thought out, and 
introduce concepts that many high school students don't really learn in 
high school. The mix of pop culture (thug) and academia (notes) is very 
well done. The comedy is not distracting from the important motifs and 
themes that are so thoroughly explained. Honestly, I have to be grateful 
that youtube gives the opportunity for talented people like Wisecrack to do 
such amazing things and provide amazing educational material that teenagers 
will actually enjoy watching. I am actually very disappointed by some of 
these comments made by teachers, who clearly don't understand that this is 
what teenagers are entertained by.  Btw, I'd love to see some Jane Austen 
up in here, G. ﻿
comments.author: Maria Pepelassis

comments.author: Erika Ortiz

comments.text:
+paulagcs
I appreciate your input. Very insightful. I agree. I've just been stuck in 
a bind of representing my initial position. The good thing to come out of 
it is that we're discussing what's being depicted.

One thing I'd like to point out, though, is that rich white heterosexual 
males are also expected to uphold the rich-white-hetersexual-male 
stereotype in this and many other environments. The state of identity and 
identity politics (especially in America) has developed into such an absurd 
distortion of ordinary life that the class which is supposed to be on the 
top of the "Pyramid of Privilege", if you will, are a parody of themselves. 
Which behaviours or signs of difference must a straight white man suppress 
to fit the expectations of his peers, black and white women, black men, 
queer people, and every other identity supposedly under his thumb?

Just a thought - and it's particularly noticeable to me as I'm Irish and 
never experienced privilege over others, except maybe from all that cheap 
slave-labour clothing and Chinese gadgets... but as I prepare to integrate 
in America, I'm the white devil!
comments.author: Silver Pill

comments.text:
+Silver Pill I have to admit that at first I had mixed feelings about this 
video as well, exactly due to the stereotype it depicts. I think dealing 
with oppressed ethnic groups is always hard because people who have 
suffered from this oppression might be offended no matter what you do, 
because since individuals have different life stories... while some of them 
might relate to the character, others will see him exactly as the 
stereotype they have spent their entire lives trying to deconstruct.

The point is that, in the end, both approaches are equally valid in my 
opinion, and though maybe this channel can't cover them all, I think it is 
a valid contribution.

While I do believe that black people shouldn't be depicted as "thugs" all 
the time, I think that "silencing the thugs" in ALL media is just as 
controversial. As some have already mentioned here, millions of people DO 
relate to the character and, with that in mind, I love the fact that they 
prove you CAN be a thug with PhD in literature, for example, that 
expressing your culture is not incompatible with being highly educated. 

Most of the time, you have to mimic the rich-white-heterosexual-male 
stereotype to be taken seriously in an intellectual environment. Gays 
shouldn't be flamboyant, women should be sober, blacks shouldn't use the 
language they learned in the ghetto (or any other differences that the 
dominant group doesn't like seeing in others). And yes, that goes too to 
the red neck you mentioned. Anyone who has been to college as part of these 
"minorities" (who, in fact, are not minorities at all) has been through it.

(Of course it doesn't mean that ALL gay people are indeed flamboyant or ALL 
black people relate to the "thug" culture. Actually, no matter what group 
you belong to, first... you are an individua and individuals are different. 
Even if you are rich, male, heterossexual and white, you won't relate to 
all other rich, straight, white males.)

Though Wisecrack fails to give voice to ALL these groups, I do think it is 
nice that they are helping push these boundaries further.
comments.author: paulagcs

comments.text:
+Silver Pill I actually don't think it's satire at all. It appears to me 
that the best intention of this video series is to be relate-able. There 
are many, many African-American youths who are thugs, who are also forced 
to read many of these books in high school. Now they have a video series 
that uses their cultural slang to hopefully give them a better 
understanding and appreciation of these books.

That I and any others find it amusing is something else.
comments.author: Maokai Hecarim

comments.text:
+mano da Silva
I'm not black, but I get the impression that the character does add to the 
whole idea that intelligence and civilization comes by being an upper-class 
WASP.
Just now I'm wondering why we don't see a redneck talking like a hick, but 
being super articulate and insightful in a salon. White people don't care 
about their deprived class, but they like to reference *your* deprived 
class.

Nah. I'm still not seeing this as innocent satire.
comments.author: Silver Pill

comments.text:
+Silver Pill This show is a satirical presentation of that narrow black 
representation in the media.  In that this is a "thug" that is literate, 
intelligent, while using the form of speech common in his culture.  At any 
case there is nothing wrong with being a "thug."  What is problematic for 
me is if black people felt they had to emulate a white dominant cultural 
motif to be considered intelligent.
comments.author: mano mononymous

comments.text:

Sorry if I bored you. The realm of words has too much space in my life.
Peace
comments.author: Silver Pill

comments.text:
+Silver Pill fair enough. I see where you're coming from, although I don't 
have anything against the video. I agree that social stereotypes of any 
kind are ridiculous and have a negative psychological impact on people, no 
matter how comical their intention. I still think the videos are done in a 
great format, stereotype aside. Also, that is a way long response. Cool 
beans, man.
comments.author: Lumpawarrump scarred me for life

comments.text:
+Lumpawarrump scarred me for life
﻿
Bollocks G+ and your little pop-out window that closes if you're not 
careful.

Just to get this out of the way, I'm an Irish National Socialist and 
married to an African-American. Not trying to invoke authority, just 
relaying why I have much to say on this. Race, culture, and Volk/Folk is 
important to me. I don't fuck around or take sides.

What's "grossly offensive"? I'd rather you asked one of the handful of 
African-Americans who agreed with my initial instinct about this video. 
Only they can tell you what it means. *Granted:* We're getting into the 
realm of emotions here and pretty much giving people the right to be 
offended by anything, but there's an actual basis in reality to this, and 
it's our job to figure out what's a genuine social complaint.
If this video was in a different social context, where the vast majority of 
African-Americans depicted in "white" literature and media weren't 
constantly coloured by destructive stereotypes and didn't teach young 
African-American kids that all they're allowed to be is one of this narrow 
array of dysfunctional Human, *then this depiction would be harmless*. Yet 
it's the only African-American I've seen in the handful of videos from this 
channel, and he's a fucking street hustler.
I think Peggy MacIntosh's "White Privilege" concept is really flawed, but 
there's some truth in there to be redeemed. We may casually write or watch 
a black character "being black" and our lack of social context won't give 
us the eyes to see content that could be harmful, and the African-Americans 
are starting to forget what derides them because they've been brow-beaten 
with transgressive depictions and role models of themselves for 40 years 
now. Even on BET, the best you can hope to look up to is some Uncle Tom... 
why do you think, despite the shallowness and backstabbing, 
African-Americans are FANATICAL about Barack Obama? That's the closest 
thing they've got to a progress and intelligent role model who isn't 
speaking from a standpoint of being oppressed.
This is not a good climate for Americans of any colour. Y'all are living on 
top of each other and the continents ye came from don't want ye back - the 
United States is your home. You should be caring for it and each other in 
that spirit. If you were two neighbouring countries you could do what 
everyone else does: escalate into warfare and then get sick of it after a 
generation or two, then become friends. That's not an option. The lower 
down one element of society is cast, the more animosity, which has nowhere 
to go.

So I hope you can see that I recognise your attempt to turn the whole thing 
180 and I hope you recognise I met you half way. I wouldn't have come back 
if I didn't enjoy good discourse and sharing.


P.S. I'm not buying the Cultural Marxist crap that everything should be 
derided. Levity and satire are powerful social weapons, we can't afford to 
wave them around cutting down every tree that stands. I hope you recognise 
that there in fact are things one shouldn't make light of on the personal 
level at least. Our culture isn't wholly defective and needing to be 
scrapped.
comments.author: Silver Pill

As a communist myself, I think Orwell's work is important.  The idea of

comments.text:
Nm, he did mention the allegory of the conflict. He just didn't mention the

comments.author: Nathan Payne

comments.text:
Along with that detail I just pointed out, another detail that the host 
didn't mention in the analysis section was the allegory and the symbolism 
of the conflict between snowball and Napoleon. Snowball represented leon 
trotsky whereas Napoleon represented stalin. Although George Orwell 
admitted that he was not a Trotskyist, the book could be interpreted that 
snowball helped steered the farm into a becoming a genuine socialist 
society. It was only when Napoleon kicked him out and took over that things 
started to head downhill.

With that said, of course, if you're a stalinist or a stalinist 
sympathizer, you'll still most likely dislike the book since stalinism, not 
socialism, is what it cricriticizes. It's just nice to keep these things in 
mind in case a libertarian ever tries to use the book as a criticism 
against socialism. Just point out George Orwell being a socialist and 
usually the arguing quickly ends. The book is also good for those that are 
interested in political theory.
comments.author: Nathan Payne

comments.text:
George Orwell was a self proclaimed democratic socialist. He was just a 
socialist that didn't like stalin.

comments.author: Millie Burton

comments.text:
+18807BB
It's not PC culture. Come on, get real. It's polite society.
What does Animal Farm have to do with expletives? How do you propose that 
schoolkids can gain a deeper understanding of this social allegory by 
cursing and using street slang?
Think about it.

The only reason I'm calling you on this is because the inevitable result is 
going in the extreme direction in the absence of reasonable restrictions.
Like this:
http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1376506/Children-young-11-offered-free-condoms-mail-health-authority-Takecontrolphilly-org.html


The Japanese, I think, have an important tip for us when it comes to the 
mix between the profane and the sacred. They were always very conservative 
(in the past), and didn't even discuss religion. They knew it was an 
arbitrary prohibition, but they also knew you needed an arbitrary 
prohibition. Gotta protect the mystery around these things.
comments.author: Silver Pill

comments.text:
Its really dumb that schools force that kind of censorship, or more 
appropriately that parents force that kind of censorship. If you're reading 
Animal Farm in school then you are dealing with some grown up issues, time 
to stop sugar coating shit and tell kids how it is. I don't see how they 
would even begin to understand the implications of the book if they are 
that sheltered.

The PC culture did nothing for me in school. When I saw a school official 
trying to censor something like that it just showed me how illegitimate 
their authority was. The education system is kind of fucked.
comments.author: 18807BB

comments.text: LOL you're watching thug notes angry that someone said ass.

comments.text:
By censoring the video you are changing the whole entire point of the 
video. The series is supposed to be a comedic (yet truthful and in-depth) 
analysis of respected literary works, told by the point of view of a 
stereotypical person born in the African-American hood. The language and 
slurs are a large part of it. You came here for his point of view and you 
stayed for the comedy and knowledge. You wouldn't try to censor "The 
Catcher in the Rye", why would you try to censor this man (who is an actor).
comments.author: luf4rall

comments.text:
+dakotadenverdexter
If we're going to be using strict Left Wing lingo here, that's not for you 
to decide. As the oppressed class black people reserve the right to deem 
any depiction of themselves as racist. My black wife and others would say 
this is racist. You (and I) as the oppressor, who have the upper-hand in 
the cultural narrative, are not in a position to argue that point.

This is an unhealthy depiction of an African-American. The problem comes in 
when you don't recognise that. If you had a variety of personality when it 
comes to black people in our media, you'd be able to tell the difference 
and this would be an isolated incident of, merely, a depiction of a single 
stereotype. This depiction is healthy to you, in other words.
Hope I didn't make that too convoluted.

There's also the *particular use* of the "hip hop stereotype", as it's not 
being used in isolation. Here we see our thug in a salon. What the fuck is 
a brotha doin' in a salon? Part of the humour is the clear difference 
between the man and his environment.
It's abusive rubbish. The only reason it's still here is because you and 
the others are into the subject of discussion enough that it doesn't bother 
you. Lesser offenses have resulted in white people reading off the "I'm so, 
so, sorry. Can I have my job back?" script.
comments.author: Silver Pill

comments.text:
+Silver Pill White Supremacy =/= Hip-Hop stereotypes.  It's only when they

population) that we have a problem.

comments.text:
Please don't show this to children... we have enough White Supremacy in the

comments.author: Silver Pill

comments.text:
+Kate Pece
Thank you for spelling it out. I've been "schooled".


You're right: "I'd like to say that I'm shocked by the hateful commentary 
above, but sadly, I'm not. I feel sorry for you that you had such awful 
teachers that you gleefully smear a teacher you don't know nor have ever 
seen teach. I'm saddened that one harmless comment about how I wanted to 
share this video with my students turned into so much venom. You deserved 
better teachers than you had."

My opinion of teachers is very low, and it was from experience. I've had 
many many teachers, and very few of them were any good. If every time you 
went to a restaurant the waiters were absolute douchebags, and most 
restaurants turned out the same, you'd have a very low opinion of both 
waiters and restaurants.
comments.author: Albert B

comments.text:
+Albert B YouTube doesn't format threads this way, but I was specifically 
referring to this response from you:

"Simply find something else to give 8th graders. The rest of us like what 
we are hearing/seeing. Stop trying to censor other people's work and make 
your own material. Of course, you are a teacher, so I'm not sure you're 
creative enough to get the job done. Your skill is telling others' what to 
do."

Your first statement at least referred back to my comment. The rest of your 
commentary contains at least three logical fallacies:

1) I wasn't trying to censor anyone by wishing there were an alternate 
version (red herring). 
2) I'm not too lazy to create my own material (non sequitur). When 
something is already well done, you want to share it---and keep your job.
3) Although you know nothing about my creativity or skill, you imply that I 
have little of both (sweeping generalization). 

In addition to teaching allegory, satire, historical context and logical 
fallacies, I also teach my students to cite evidence from the text to back 
up their thinking. It's only fair that I should do the same.
comments.author: Kate Pece

comments.text:
+Albert B My original post stated, "I only wish you offered an alternate 
censored version...". I'd like to highlight the use of the word *alternate.* 
I greatly enjoy Thug Notes as it is, and it is not lost on me that the 
irreverence and cursing *makes* it satire. As much as I love Thug Notes, 
however, I love having a meaningful career even more. I would be stupid to 
risk my job teaching kids over something like a couple of curse words. 

Clearly you are not a teacher and cannot appreciate the risks your own 
teachers may have taken in using unapproved materials or language in your 
classes. In my experience, you will not find a more irreverent, 
iconoclastic, sarcastic, subversive group of teachers than those in the 
English department (although social studies teachers give us a good run for 
the money). We believe in freedom of expression, and we revere the spoken 
and written word---even the "bad' ones. 

I'd like to say that I'm shocked by the hateful commentary above, but 
sadly, I'm not. I feel sorry for you that you had such awful teachers that 
you gleefully smear a teacher you don't know nor have ever seen teach. I'm 
saddened that one harmless comment about how I *wanted* to share this video 
with my students turned into so much venom. You deserved better teachers 
than you had.

I challenge you and all of the other cranky teacher-haters who posted here 
to become teachers yourselves. Show us losers how it's done while we keep 
enjoying our fat paychecks, short working hours, and long summers 
frolicking on the French Riviera. (BTW, that was sarcasm, if you missed it.)
comments.author: Kate Pece

comments.text:
+Kate Pece
I'm going to double down on my opinion that you're a terrible teacher if 
you're calling my comments a "red herring". Typically, you would need to 
point out where that herring is at, instead of just yelling nonsense. I 
would expect nothing less from a teacher who wants to use someone else to 
teach their class. If you were intelligent enough, you could make your own 
lessons and not want to just laze out and show YouTube videos to your class.
comments.author: Albert B

comments.text:
We could have a family reunion-style fish fry around here. Now I know who 
didn't pay attention in high school English class.

comments.author: Will Ferrous

comments.text:
+Will Ferrous
Your supposed example of Communism is incorrect.

Defining Communism-Communism (from Latin communis – common, universal) is a 
socioeconomic system structured upon the common ownership of the means of 
production and characterized by the absence of social classes, money, and 
the state; as well as a social, political and economic ideology and 
movement that aims to establish this social order.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Communism
--------------------------------------------------------------
What you are referring to is most likely State Capitalism.

Defining State Capitalism-State capitalism is usually described as an 
economic system in which commercial (i.e. for-profit) economic activity is 
undertaken by the state, with management and organization of the means of 
production in a capitalist manner, including the system of capital 
accumulation, wage labor, and centralized management.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_capitalism
-------------------------------------------------------------
State Capitalism was created by Lenin and the Bolshevik (Soviet 
Government), to further accumulate power into there own hands and suppress 
the working classes.
comments.author: Comrade Kearsey

comments.text:
+Pinkie D. Luffy No no, this isn't about blaming the Russians at all. My 
point was that socialism was a Trojan horse gifted on Russia from Germany. 
Economically, Germany did wunderbar while Russia starved. Germany just 
didn't realize how fucking tough Russians were when they attacked in the 
middle of winter.

My larger point is that socialism was never meant to help anybody as it was 
designed as a means to destroy societies. Marx' theory is predicated on a 
self-fulfilling prophecy. It's intent was to sow discontent among workers 
(and peasants) and force them into a state-sponsored union. Most of us just 
call that subjugation, with the illusion of democratic control. This is 
why, as America becomes more socialist, we see a growing gap between 
ourselves and our democracy. It's all been taken up by little unions 
(special interests), from Big Oil to Big Welfare. The everyday person has 
no say, no power, no control. Either get on a shareholders board, or join 
the upper echelons of the LGBT rights committees if you want to help direct 
the future of America. This is what socialism does. And this is what a rant 
looks like. :D
comments.author: Albert B
